etymologies: late 17th century: from medieval Latin fungibilis, from fungi ‘perform, enjoy’, with the same sense as fungi vice ‘serve in place of’

definitions: (of goods contracted for without an individual specimen being specified) able to replace or be replaced by another identical item; mutually interchangeable

examples.text: it is by no means the world's only fungible commodity
money is fungible—money that is raised for one purpose can easily be used for another

shortDefinitions: (of goods contracted for without individual specimen being specified) replaceable by another identical item
